FIRST MEETING OF
FENCING TEAM HELD
AT BARN SATURDAY

As long as football has been given a vacation this past week-end,
let's
look in on some of the other sports around the campus and get
the low down
their most recent experience.
Soccer
We see that our soccer hopefuls failed by one point
in their most
crucial game to date. They say that a victory over Maryland, Saturday,
would
have put us in line for the State Championship this year. But
those inconsiderate Terps put the skids under our boys and Trinaned them
handily by
a 2-1 score. How "handily" they did clip us in a matter of
question, however.
Eye witnesses of the contest have it that we outplayed our
College Park
rivals and really deserved to win. 'fhe referee, it seems,
must have had
his mind on something other than the struggle under his
supervision, for he
was guilty of a couple of glaring Anti-Blue Jay boners.
But we shouldn't
be too selfish; after all, it was home-coming day for Maryland,
and they
were a little scared of losingthat pigskin tussle with
Florida.
Cross Country
The Cross-County result was just exactly as we had expected.
Swarthmore trounced us thanks to their better-balanced squad, but
Driscoll was
the best man on the course. Johnny lived up to his reputation
and deserves
additional praise for out-running the last barriers of a good
Swarthmore
team. With a little more help, we inay be able to do better in
our next
try.

Basketball
Tr -weekly practice sessions have begun to straighten out our
Basketball affairs. The quintet ought to be plenty tall as a result of the
acquisition of McClain, former Washington College court-man. We're waiting
for
Utz Twardewicz to take over controls until Coach Mallonee
comes home
from the football wars. Until then, there can be no definite news
as to the
possible starting five. Right now every candidate has a chance;
and even
the captain himself can't be too sure of his position.

Lacrosse
Finally, from the Lacrosse front, we hear that there are quite anumber
taking the Fall practices indeed earnest. Coach Morrill is having his
charges hustle in preparation for the Spring campaign. We can't tell
yet
how good a club we're going to have, but judging by the rate at which
those
hockey-handlers are traveling, we have shaped up with the best of them.

tain other ones. These other organisms in turn refused to conjugate
among themselves but would pair
with the first. Thus the race could
be divided into two kinds: members
of one conjugating only with those
of the other but not with members
of its own group. These two types
he called Sex I and Sex II.
Further investigation showed that
the inheritance of sex among descendants of a pair of conjugants
follows the Mendelian Laws, that unlike higher organism a sex n and IV
could be found in other races which
would pair with each other but not
with sex I and n, and other more
complicated relationships, between
the various types.

FIRST MEETING OF
FENCING TEAM HELD
AT BARN SATURDAY

As long as football has been given a vacation this past week-end,
let's
look in on some of the other sports around the campus and get
the low down
their most recent experience.
Soccer
We see that our soccer hopefuls failed by one point
in their most
crucial game to date. They say that a victory over Maryland, Saturday,
would
have put us in line for the State Championship this year. But
those inconsiderate Terps put the skids under our boys and Trinaned them
handily by
a 2-1 score. How "handily" they did clip us in a matter of
question, however.
Eye witnesses of the contest have it that we outplayed our
College Park
rivals and really deserved to win. 'fhe referee, it seems,
must have had
his mind on something other than the struggle under his
supervision, for he
was guilty of a couple of glaring Anti-Blue Jay boners.
But we shouldn't
be too selfish; after all, it was home-coming day for Maryland,
and they
were a little scared of losingthat pigskin tussle with
Florida.
Cross Country
The Cross-County result was just exactly as we had expected.
Swarthmore trounced us thanks to their better-balanced squad, but
Driscoll was
the best man on the course. Johnny lived up to his reputation
and deserves
additional praise for out-running the last barriers of a good
Swarthmore
team. With a little more help, we inay be able to do better in
our next
try.

Basketball
Tr -weekly practice sessions have begun to straighten out our
Basketball affairs. The quintet ought to be plenty tall as a result of the
acquisition of McClain, former Washington College court-man. We're waiting
for
Utz Twardewicz to take over controls until Coach Mallonee
comes home
from the football wars. Until then, there can be no definite news
as to the
possible starting five. Right now every candidate has a chance;
and even
the captain himself can't be too sure of his position.

Lacrosse
Finally, from the Lacrosse front, we hear that there are quite anumber
taking the Fall practices indeed earnest. Coach Morrill is having his
charges hustle in preparation for the Spring campaign. We can't tell
yet
how good a club we're going to have, but judging by the rate at which
those
hockey-handlers are traveling, we have shaped up with the best of them.

among themselves but would pair

of its own group. These two types
he called Sex I and Sex II.
Further investigation showed that
the inheritance of sex among descendants of a pair of conjugants
follows the Mendelian Laws, that unlike higher organism a sex n and IV
could be found in other races which
would pair with each other but not
with sex I and n, and other more
complicated relationships, between
the various types.
